clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Paroxetine on Smokers' Cardiovascular Response to Stress - 1
clinical_study.official_title: Smoking, Antidepressants, and Response to Mental Stress

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Minnesota - Clinical and Translational Science Institute

clinical_study.source: University of Minnesota - Clinical and Translational Science Institute

brief_summary.textblock: Smokers report that they often smoke cigarettes during stressful times. The combined effect of smoking and exposure to stress leads to exaggerated increases in blood pressure, heart rate and other measures of stress response. This combination may result in greater cardiovascular harm than either smoking or stress alone. The purpose of this study is to determine the effects of paroxetine on the response to stress after smoking.

detailed_description.textblock:
Smokers report that they often smoke cigarettes during stressful times. Smoking and stress produce similar physiological responses such as increases in heart rate, blood pressure, and adrenaline levels. The combination of smoking and stress results in greater increases in these physiological responses compared to smoking or stress alone. Such increases are thought to be harmful to cardiovascular health. Additionally, smokers with exaggerated responses to stress may be more likely to relapse following a smoking cessation attempt. The purpose of this study is to assess the effects of paroxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), on the cardiovascular response to stress after smoking.
Participants in this double-blind, placebo-controlled study will receive 1 month of paroxetine and 1 month of placebo with the order of which is taken during the first month randomly assigned. Paroxetine will be administered at a daily dose of 10 mg for the first week and increased to a daily dose of 20 mg for the remainder of the study. After one month of medication, participants will abstain from smoking for one night and then undergo mental stress testing the following day. Immediately prior to the mental stress testing, participants will smoke a cigarette. Mental stressors will include speaking and math tasks. Physiological measures of stress (e.g., blood pressure, heart rate, and plasma catecholamine concentrations) and subjective measures of stress will be evaluated. Following the second month of medication, participants will again undergo the procedure for mental stress testing and evaluation.

primary_outcome.measure: Systolic Blood Pressure Response to Stress
primary_outcome.description: Change in systolic blood pressure from Resting period to that observed during a speech delivered immediately after smoking a cigarette

other_outcome.measure: Diastolic Blood Pressure Response to Stress
other_outcome.description: Change in diastolic blood pressure from Resting period to that observed during a speech delivered immediately after smoking a cigarette
Change in heart rate from Resting period to that observed during a speech delivered immediately after smoking a cigarette

other_outcome.measure: Plasma Epinephrine Concentration Response to Stress
other_outcome.description: Change in plasma epinephrine concentrations from Resting period to those observed during a speech delivered immediately after smoking a cigarette

other_outcome.measure: Plasma Norepinephrine Concentration Response to Stress
other_outcome.description: Change in plasma norepinephrine concentrations from Resting period to those observed during a speech delivered immediately after smoking a cigarette

arm_group.description: Active medication for 4 weeks followed by placebo for 4 weeks
Placebo for 4 weeks followed by active for 4 weeks

intervention.description: 10 mg for 1 week followed by 20 mg for 3 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Smokes an average of at least 10 cigarettes per day during the year prior to enrollment
Exclusion Criteria:
- Interested in quitting smoking within the 3 months following enrollment
- Current unstable medical condition
- Substance abuse within the year prior to enrollment
- Current use of any medications (e.g., psychoactive medications, antihypertensives) that, in the opinion of the investigators, might interfere with study measures or that would be expected to interact with paroxetine (e.g., CYP2D6 substrates)
- Smoking cessation therapy within the 3 months prior to enrollment
- Regular use of any form of tobacco other than cigarettes
- Significant psychiatric disorders as assessed by the PRIME-MD and verified by a clinician
- History of hypersensitivity to any selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor
- Pregnancy or breastfeeding

group.title: Placebo (4 Weeks) Then Paroxetine (4 Weeks)
group.description: Placebo once daily in first intervention period and Paroxetine 10 mg daily for 1 week then increased to 20 mg once daily for remainder of second intervention period

group.title: Paroxetine (4 Weeks) the Placebo (4 Weeks)
group.description: Paroxetine 10 mg daily for 1 week then increased to 20 mg once daily for remainder of first intervention period, placebo once daily in second intervention period

baseline.population: Includes subjects who completed both laboratory sessions (n=62). One additional subject completed both laboratory sessions but did not have usable measures in the primary outcomes (cardiovascular measures) and was excluded

group.title: Placebo First 4 Weeks, Then Paroxetine for 4 Weeks
group.description: Placebo once daily in first intervention period and Paroxetine 10 mg daily for 1 week then increased to 20 mg once daily for remainder of second intervention period

group.description: Paroxetine 10 mg daily for 1 week then increased to 20 mg once daily for remainder of first intervention period, placebo once daily in second intervention period

reported_events.desc: Subjects were asked at each visit an open ended question if they've experienced any side effects

group.description: Participants receive placebo daily for 4 weeks

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
